docs.lead_paragraph: It sounds like the beginning of a teaching case for medical students: A 14-year-old girl with a chief complaint of abdominal pain. How the story unfolds could turn out to be a lesson in the difficulty of diagnosing appendicitis, or a reminder that there are many different organs that can cause pain in the general region of the abdomen -- the digestive system, the urinary tract and, of course, the reproductive system. Abdominal pain in an adolescent girl can have a simple common explanation -- chronic constipation, say, or acute gastroenteritis -- but it cannot be taken for granted as a simple question.

headline.main: Connecting the Symptoms, From Skin to Joints to Abdomen

docs.abstract: Dr Perri Klass Cases column describes disease Henoch-Schonlein purpura and its symptoms; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Abdominal pain in an adolescent girl can have a simple common explanation, but it cannot be taken for granted as a simple question.

docs.lead_paragraph: Massages, aromatherapy and even karaoke nights helped reduce pain in nursing home residents, researchers have found. So did taking a more systematic approach to the use of prescription drugs. The study was initiated by the Centers for Medicaid and Medicare Services, the federal agency that administers both programs, and involved the collaboration of eight large nursing home companies.
docs.abstract: Study initiated by Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services suggests that there are many different ways to reduce pain in nursing home residents; Dr David Gifford of Brown University, who helped conduct study, holds that nurses and nurses' aides should be given freedom to work directly with patients and figure out methods to manage pain; non-medical and alternative therapies described; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Massages, aromatherapy and even karaoke nights helped reduce pain in nursing home residents, researchers have found.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR MEDICARE AND MEDICAID SERVICES

docs.lead_paragraph: People who survive cancer appear to get worse care than the general population when it comes to other diseases, a study released last week concluded. According to the study, published in the online version of the journal Cancer, the number of cancer survivors, which is over eight million in the United States today, is increasing as treatments improve.
docs.abstract: Dr Craig C Earle of Dana Farber Cancer Institute leads research published in online version of journal Cancer that shows cancer survivors do not receive adequate medical treatment compared to other patients; suggests doctors focus too heavily on possible cancer recurrence at expense of treating other possible health concerns; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People who survive cancer appear to get worse care than the general population when it comes to other diseases, a study released last week concluded.

docs.lead_paragraph: Former President Bill Clinton's quadruple bypass surgery two weeks ago sent many middle-aged men rushing to have their hearts checked. As one, a heart surgeon, put it: ''Bill's case scares us baby boomers out of our minds.''

headline.main: Heart-Health Lessons From the Clinton Case

docs.abstract: Former President Bill Clinton's recent health crisis that led to his quadruple bypass surgery at New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center described; course of treatment prior to and after surgery, which includes taking statins to lower cholesterol, discussed; public figures who become ill can often inspire, inform and motivate individuals to take better care of themselves; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Former President Bill Clinton's quadruple bypass surgery two weeks ago sent many middle-aged men rushing to have their hearts checked.

docs.lead_paragraph: Where do dreams come from? Scientists have debated the question for decades. But Swiss researchers last week reported new clues from the case of a woman who temporarily lost her ability to dream after a stroke, even though she still had periods of rapid eye movement sleep or R.E.M. sleep, also called ''dream sleep,'' every night. The report, published in The Annals of Neurology, said a few instances of dream loss after stroke have been reported through the years. But it has always been one of many symptoms -- patients also often lost their ability to distinguish familiar faces or surroundings.
docs.abstract: Dr Matthias Bischof and colleagues at University Hospital of Zurich report in Annals of Neurology case of woman who lost ability to dream after stroke, but still maintained REM state sleep; research suggests that dreaming and REM sleep may be independent entities (S)
docs.snippet: Where do dreams come from? A new report may shed some clues.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Stress Cure,'' by Dr. Vern S. Cherewatenko and Paul Perry. HarperCollins, $24.95. ''User's Guide to Stress-Busting Nutrients,'' by RoseMarie Gionta Alfieri. Basic Health Publications, $5.95.
docs.abstract: Dr Vern S Cherewatenko and Paul Perry book The Stress Cure addresses women's concerns about how stress can impact overall health and well-being; provides nutritional strategies for dealing with stress; RoseMarie Gionta Alfieri book User's Guide to Stress-Busting Nutrients relies on specific supplements to reduce harmful stress, but acknowledges that behavioral and life style changes are important in conquering stress; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The effectiveness of over-the-counter nutritional supplements these authors recommend has been disputed by some experts.

docs.lead_paragraph: Elevated blood sugar increases the risk of heart disease, not only in people with diabetes but also in those with high-normal readings not considered diabetic. Two new studies provide strong evidence that the increased risk is due to blood sugar itself, independent of other problems that often go along with it, like high blood pressure and cholesterol. Before the studies, diabetes was already known to be bad for the heart: it doubles the risk of dying from cardiovascular disease, and 70 to 80 percent of people with diabetes die from heart attacks, strokes and artery disease. But researchers were not sure whether to blame blood sugar, or only the associated risk factors.

headline.main: High Blood Sugar Also Poses Risk to Heart

docs.abstract: New studies find link between high blood sugar and cardiovascular disease; research, published in Annals of Internal Medicine, suggests that blood sugar threshold of 7 percent may be too high and doctors need to perform further tests on individuals with readings of 5 percent or higher; Dr Hertzel C Gerstein, McMaster University endocrinologist, writes editorial to accompany new studies suggesting doctors use current tests to determine heart risk for diabetics as tool to assess risk of cardiovascular disease in those individuals who are not diabetic (M)
docs.snippet: Elevated blood sugar increases the risk of heart disease, not only in people with diabetes but also in those with high-normal readings not considered diabetic.

docs.lead_paragraph: You may think that a genuine interest in consumer health prompts food companies to market products that claim to reduce the risk of heart disease or cancer or help people lose weight. Think again. Many food companies are interested in one thing -- the most efficient route to extra sales. The more products consumers buy and the more of them they eat, the fatter the companies' coffers. And, alas, the fatter the consumers are likely to be, as well.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses food products that claim to be good for consumers; Dr Marion Nestle, former head of nutrition and now professor of public health at New York University, holds that food companies use claims to distract public from noticing caloric content under guise that any quantity of consumption is acceptable since product is healthy; low carbohydrate trend discussed; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: You may think that a genuine interest in consumer health prompts food companies to market supposedly healthful products. Think again.

docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, a federal advisory panel urged regulators to warn parents that antidepressant drugs not only increase the risk of suicide in some children, but that most have a poor track record in curing their disease. The recommendation came after a yearlong debate over whether the drugs are as safe and effective as advertised. It was based on evidence that a small minority of children show increased signs of suicidal behavior when taking the drugs.

headline.main: Is Prozac Better? Is It Even Different?

docs.abstract: Federal advisory panel, looking into concerns that some antidepressant drugs could increase risk of suicide in young people, suggests that drugs have labels warning patents of possible risks; Prozac, which was first antidepressant of its class, remains only antidepressant approved by Food and Drug Administration for treatment of depression in children and adolescents; Dr Steven Hyman, National Institute of Mental Health former director, holds that since Prozac works on same principle as other drugs in its class there should be no difference in how they impact patients; clinical trials on Prozac and possible reasons why drug might work differently discussed; suicide risk is highest for antidepressants in first three to four weeks of treatment; photo (L)
docs.snippet: Through all the recent warnings about antidepressants and children, one of the drugs seemed somehow above the fray: Prozac. But is it really that different?

docs.lead_paragraph: Grace Drake still hopes that someday she will meet Mr. Right and have a family the old-fashioned way. But as the program director of a fertility clinic in Austin, Tex., Ms. Drake, 35, sees women every day who are in their 30's and 40's and want desperately to have children but cannot. So she decided to take out some insurance: She froze her eggs.

headline.main: For Women Worried About Fertility, Egg Bank Is a New Option

docs.abstract: Extend Fertility, company that offers egg freezing to women wanting to preserve ability to have children later in life, now has clinics in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Dallas and New York; only around 100 babies worldwide have been born using frozen eggs; Christy Jones, Harvard University MBA and founder of company, acknowledges that process is expensive, but holds that all fertility-related procedures have high price tag; process of freezing eggs, which requires dehydration to prevent damaging ice crystals from forming, described; American Society for Reproductive Medicine warns that freezing eggs should not be used as way for older women to have babies, but recognizes that technology is advancing at rapid pace; photos (M)
docs.snippet: For single women who want children, egg freezing may be a reproductive insurance policy.
